metadata.titleEn: SMAP soil moisture and vegetation optical depth product using MCCA (2015-2024)
metadata.description:
Soil moisture is an important boundary condition of earth-atmosphere exchanges, and it has been defined as an essential climate variable by GCOS. Vegetation optical depth is a physical variable to measure the attenuation of vegetation in microwave radiative transfer model, and it has been proved to be a good indicator of vegetation water content and biomass.
This dataset uses the multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) to retrieve both soil moisture and polarized vegetation optical depth with SMAP brightness temperature. The algorithm uses a self-constraint relationship between land parameters and an analytical relationship between brightness temperature at different channels to perform the retrieval process. The MCCA does not depend on other auxiliary data on vegetation properties and can be applied to a variety of satellites. The soil moisture product from this dataset includes the soil moisture content in the unfrozen period and the liquid water content in the frozen period. Both horizontal- and vertical-polarization vegetation optical depth are retrieved. So far as we know, it is the first polarization-dependent vegetation optical depth product at L-band.
This dataset was validated by 19 dense soil moisture observation networks (9 core validation sites used by SMAP team and 13 sites not used by them), and the widely used soil climate analysis network (SCAN). It was found that ubRMSE (unbiased root mean square error) of MCCA retrieved soil moisture is generally smaller than that of other SMAP products.
metadata.instructions:
Data file naming method:
<MCCA_SMAP_xxKM_CCFP_VSM_VOD_YYYY_V0.nc>, MCCA represents the multi-channel collaborative algorithm, SMAP represents the SMAP satellite, <xxKM> represents the grid size of ease grid 2.0 projection, <CCFP> indicates F-band (F is frequency) brightness temperature of P polarization was used as the core channel in MCCA, VSM_VOD is the product of soil moisture and vegetation optical thickness, <YYYYMMDD> is the year, month and date of the data, and V1 represents the data version, which will be updated according to your valuable suggestions.
usage method:
Data can be read in various programming languages such as MATLAB, Python and IDL, and can also be visualized in hdfview and panoply. Please refer to the description document for details. We provide Python and Matlab code to read and plot data.

background: Due to the success of the SMOS (Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity) and SMAP (Soil Moisture Active Passive) missions, new satellite missions are on the horizon. The current and future missions can benefit from investigations that seek to improve retrieval algorithms that quantitatively map global soil moisture and vegetation optical depth (tau) from Earth’s microwave emissions. Soil moisture information is critically important in hydrological processes due to its relationships with land surface evapotranspiration, runoff, precipitation, and infiltration.
research objective: In this study, we explore multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches for the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation tau, considering the payload configurations of current and future satellite missions (such as the Copernicus Imaging Microwave Radiometer, the Water Cycle Observation Mission, and the Terrestrial Water Resources Satellite) using a new set of ground observations.
challenges: It is affirmed that increasing the number of observation channels could make the soil moisture retrieval more robust, but might also limit the retrieval performance, as the probability that the model estimations will not match the observations is increased.
methods: Two ground-based microwave radiometry datasets collected in Inner Mongolia during the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River from July to August 2017 (cropland) and August to September 2018 (grassland) are used for this study. A multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) is developed based on the two-component version of the omega-tau model, which utilizes information from collaborative channels expressed as an analytical form of brightness temperature at the core channel to rule out the parameters to be retrieved.
dataset: Two ground-based microwave radiometry datasets collected in Inner Mongolia during the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River from July to August 2017 (cropland) and August to September 2018 (grassland) are used for this study.
findings: Results of soil moisture retrieval show that the multi-angular approach used by the MCCA generally has a better performance, unbiased root mean square difference (ubRMSD) varying from 0.028 cm³/cm³ to 0.037 cm³/cm³, than the multi-frequency approach (ubRMSD from 0.028 cm³/cm³ to 0.089 cm³/cm³) for the corn field. Except for in the C- & X-band combination, the multi-frequency approach used by the MCCA performs better (ubRMSD from 0.018 cm³/cm³ to 0.023 cm³/cm³) than the multi-angular version (ubRMSD from 0.026 cm³/cm³ to 0.034 cm³/cm³) for the grass field due to reduced vegetation effects for this type of cover. This study provides new insights into the design of potential satellite missions to improve soil moisture retrieval. A satellite with simultaneous multi-angular and multi-frequency observation capabilities is highly recommended.

background: Soil moisture (SM) is an important boundary condition of land-atmosphere feedbacks, and is identified as an essential climate variable by the Global Climate Observing System. Vegetation optical depth (VOD, τ) is a physical variable that describes the microwave extinction effects caused by vegetation in the microwave radiative transfer models and it provides information on both plant water status and biomass. Microwave remote sensing has good capability to retrieve SM and VOD, especially passive microwave L-band (1 – 2 GHz) because at these wavelengths the vegetation is semi-transparent, and the observed brightness temperature (Tb) is sensitive to the water content of the first few centimeters of the soil surface, and absorption and scattering have lower impacts, compared to shorter wavelengths. Current L-band passive microwave sensors on Earth-orbiting satellites include the European Space Agency's (ESA) Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity (SMOS) mission, launched in November 2009 with multi-angular and full-polarized observations and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's (NASA) Soil Moisture Active Passive (SMAP) mission, launched in January 2015 with full-polarized observations at an incidence angle of 40°. Most SM and VOD retrieval algorithms for SMAP are based on the zero-order solution of RTM, also known as the τ-ω model.
research objective: This study proposed a parameter self-calibrating framework for the multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) and presented a new SM and the first polarization-dependent VOD product based on the dual-polarized L-band observations at a fixed angle (40°) from the NASA Soil Moisture Active Passive (SMAP) mission.
challenges: Current retrieval algorithms often ignore the polarization dependence of vegetation effects. The retrieval performance is dependent on the uncertainties introduced by the auxiliary data. Since SMAP provides only two observations during an overpass, the degree of information (DoI) of Tbs can be lower than the number of unknowns (surface parameters, SM, and VOD).
methods: To reduce the usage of auxiliary data, the ergodic form of MCCA was implemented in this study, in which a series of SM values from 0.001 (unit: m3/m3) to porosity (the fraction of void space in the soil, unit: m3/m3) were set as input. The self-calibrating of Rou was carried out under two extreme conditions. For the first condition, which was assumed a smooth surface, the following procedure was followed: (1) Rou was initially set to 0 globally. Using the MCCA algorithm, 201 pairs of SM and VOD at H and V polarizations were retrieved for a range of ω from 0 to 0.2 with a step of 0.001. The bin size for DoI calculation was determined using all the 201 pairs of time series SM and H-polarized VOD. The ω value corresponding to the minimum DoI was selected as the result. (2) With the ω value obtained from step (1), 451 pairs of time series SM and VOD were retrieved using MCCA for Rou values ranging from 0 to 4.5 with a step of 0.01. The first initial Rou (Rou_init1) was optimized by minimizing the WDs calculated by SM and VOD at H-polarization.
dataset: In this study, H- and V-polarized Tb, and the surface temperature included in the SMAP Level-3 Radiometer Global Daily 36 km EASE-Grid Soil Moisture (SPL3SMP) version 8 were used to retrieve SM and VOD. The SPL3SMP is distributed by the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NDISC) and projected to the global Equal-Area Scalable Earth-2 (EASE2) grid with a spatial sampling of 36-km. Due to the heterogeneity of satellite footprints, 19 dense networks and 1 sparse network (the soil climate analysis network, SCAN) were involved to evaluate MCCA and the other five remotely sensed SM estimates, including eight networks sourced from the International Soil Moisture Network (ISMN) database, data for seven networks obtained from the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA), four additional networks accessed from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center, and the SMN-WDL network built in the Tibet Plateau, focuses on observing soil moisture, soil temperature, and freeze/thaw state. Sand and clay fractions were obtained from the global soil texture database (SoilGrids250m) for use in the dielectric model. Canopy height data were collected from the global ecosystem dynamics investigation (GEDI) Level 3 gridded mean canopy height (version 2), while above-ground biomass (version 4) was sourced from the ESA Climate Change Initiative (CCI) Programme were utilized. Total precipitation data from the ERA5-Land hourly data, converted from hourly to a daily sum, were also used in the analysis. All datasets were aggregated to align with the SMAP pixel grid size.
findings: The MCCA-derived SM exhibits the lowest unbiased root mean square deviation (ubRMSD, about 0.055 m³/m³), followed by SMAP-IB and DCA (0.061 m³/m³), with an overall Pearson’s correlation coefficient of 0.744 (SMAP-IB performed best with R = 0.764) when evaluated against in-situ observations from 18 dense soil moisture networks. The MCCA generates VOD values for both vertical and horizontal polarization, demonstrating a slight polarization difference of vegetation effect at the satellite scale. Both VODs exhibit a strong linear relationship with above-ground biomass and canopy height. The polarization difference of VODs is primarily observed in densely vegetated and arid areas.

Example.Answer: Two ground-based microwave radiometry datasets collected in Inner Mongolia during the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River from July to August 2017 (cropland) and August to September 2018 (grassland) were used for retrieving soil moisture and vegetation optical depth using a multi-channel collaborative algorithm.

Definition.Question: What is the 'multi-channel collaborative algorithm' (MCCA) in the context of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth retrieval?
Definition.Answer: The 'multi-channel collaborative algorithm' (MCCA) is a method used for retrieving soil moisture and vegetation optical depth (VOD) by utilizing information from multiple collaborative channels. It expresses these channels as an analytical form of brightness temperature at the core channel to rule out the parameters to be retrieved. The algorithm integrates a parameter self-calibrating framework to improve retrieval accuracy and reduce dependency on auxiliary data.

Definition.Question: What does 'vegetation optical depth' (VOD) represent in microwave radiative transfer models?
Definition.Answer: In microwave radiative transfer models, 'vegetation optical depth' (VOD) is a physical variable that describes the microwave extinction effects caused by vegetation. It provides information on both plant water status and biomass, reflecting the attenuation characteristics of vegetation in the microwave frequency range.

Definition.Question: What is meant by the term 'polarization-dependent VOD product' in satellite soil moisture studies?
Definition.Answer: A 'polarization-dependent VOD product' refers to vegetation optical depth values that take into account the differences in microwave signal attenuation based on the polarization (vertical or horizontal) of the observed microwave emissions. This product is derived from dual-polarized observations, allowing for a more nuanced understanding of vegetation effects at satellite scales.

Comparison.Question: How do multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches in soil moisture retrieval compare in terms of robustness and limitations when applied to different types of land cover such as cropland and grassland?
Comparison.Answer: The multi-angular approach generally has better performance than the multi-frequency approach for cropland, with unbiased root mean square difference (ubRMSD) varying from 0.028 cm³/cm³ to 0.037 cm³/cm³. However, for grassland, the multi-frequency approach performs better than the multi-angular version due to reduced vegetation effects for this type of cover, with ubRMSD from 0.018 cm³/cm³ to 0.023 cm³/cm³.

Comparison.Question: How does the parameter self-calibrating framework for the multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) differ from traditional retrieval algorithms in terms of dependency on auxiliary data and polarization considerations?
Comparison.Answer: The parameter self-calibrating framework for MCCA reduces dependency on auxiliary data by using an ergodic form of the algorithm, while traditional retrieval algorithms often depend on auxiliary data. Additionally, MCCA considers polarization dependence of vegetation effects, which is often ignored by traditional algorithms.

Interpretation.Question: How might increasing the number of observation channels affect the robustness and performance of soil moisture retrieval algorithms?
Interpretation.Answer: Increasing the number of observation channels could make the soil moisture retrieval more robust, but it might also limit the retrieval performance as the probability that the model estimations will not match the observations increases.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could multi-angular and multi-frequency observation capabilities improve the design and performance of future satellite missions for soil moisture retrieval?
Interpretation.Answer: A satellite with simultaneous multi-angular and multi-frequency observation capabilities is recommended, as the multi-angular approach generally performs better in certain conditions, while the multi-frequency approach can reduce vegetation effects in other conditions, providing more accurate soil moisture retrieval across diverse environments.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the use of multi-frequency approaches to potentially limit retrieval performance in soil moisture datasets?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Increasing the number of observation channels might enhance robustness in soil moisture retrieval, but it can also limit performance due to the increased probability that model estimations may not match observations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might a parameter self-calibrating framework be necessary in soil moisture and vegetation optical depth retrieval algorithms?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: A parameter self-calibrating framework is necessary to reduce the dependency on auxiliary data and to address the issue of polarization dependence of vegetation effects, which can introduce uncertainties in retrieval performance.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in retrieving soil moisture and vegetation optical depth using current satellite missions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges arise from the limited degree of information available from the soil moisture active passive (SMAP) observations, as the number of unknowns (surface parameters, soil moisture, and vegetation optical depth) may exceed the level of information provided by the available brightness temperature data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using a parameter self-calibrating framework for data collection in soil moisture and vegetation optical depth retrieval?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of a parameter self-calibrating framework in soil moisture and vegetation optical depth retrieval can lead to reduced dependence on auxiliary data, improved retrieval accuracy, and the ability to generate polarization-dependent vegetation optical depth products. This approach can also help in optimizing retrieval parameters, leading to more accurate representation of soil moisture and vegetation characteristics, especially in areas with diverse surface conditions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the effects on retrieval accuracy if the number of observation channels is increased in soil moisture data collection methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Increasing the number of observation channels in soil moisture data collection methods could potentially make retrieval more robust by providing additional data points; however, it might also introduce challenges by increasing the likelihood of discrepancies between model estimations and actual observations. The complexity of managing and integrating multiple channels could impose limits on retrieval performance and necessitate refined algorithms to effectively harness the additional data.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to validate soil moisture retrieval methods using dense observation networks and auxiliary datasets like the Soil Climate Analysis Network?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Validation using dense observation networks and auxiliary datasets is crucial to ascertain the accuracy and reliability of the soil moisture retrieval methods, especially given the heterogeneity of satellite footprints and the need to evaluate performance against in-situ observations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in deploying a multi-channel collaborative algorithm to retrieve soil moisture and vegetation optical depth from satellite microwave emissions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) uses a two-component version of the omega-tau model, which involves leveraging collaborative channel information expressed analytically as brightness temperature at the core channel. The process includes setting a range of soil moisture values and using these as inputs for the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth (VOD) at different polarizations, while minimizing the usage of auxiliary data. The calibration process involves adjusting parameters to optimal values by minimizing discrepancies between observed and modeled values.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can ground-based microwave radiometry datasets be utilized to improve the retrieval algorithms for soil moisture and vegetation optical depth?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Ground-based microwave radiometry datasets, such as those collected during the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River, can provide empirical data for testing and validating new retrieval algorithms. These datasets allow researchers to explore multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches, helping to identify algorithmic improvements by providing a controlled environment to assess the effectiveness of new models like the MCCA in predicting soil moisture and VOD accurately.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key challenges in reducing the reliance on auxiliary data for retrieving soil moisture and vegetation optical depth using satellite observations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A significant challenge is the inherent uncertainty introduced by auxiliary data, which can affect retrieval accuracy. Another challenge is the limited degree of information (DoI) available from satellite observations, which often provides fewer data points than required to resolve all unknown surface parameters. Implementing a self-calibrating framework within retrieval algorithms, such as the MCCA, can help overcome these challenges by calibrating parameters like roughness and soil moisture using minimal auxiliary data, based on an ergodic approach to generating potential parameter values.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth using multi-channel collaborative algorithms?
Enablement.Answer: The multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) developed for retrieving soil moisture and vegetation optical depth utilizes multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches. This algorithm benefits from the self-calibrating framework that relies on dual-polarized L-band observations, allowing for improved retrieval performance with reduced dependency on auxiliary data.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of ground-based microwave radiometry datasets enhance the accuracy of soil moisture retrieval in diverse geographical regions?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of ground-based microwave radiometry datasets, such as those collected in Inner Mongolia during soil moisture experiments, enhances the accuracy of soil moisture retrieval by providing empirical data for validating and refining retrieval algorithms. These datasets allow for the assessment of multi-angular and multi-frequency retrieval approaches, leading to improved performance metrics in varied geographical regions.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do the configuration and capabilities of satellite sensors impact the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth on a global scale?
Enablement.Answer: The configuration and capabilities of satellite sensors, such as the full-polarized observations and fixed angle of L-band passive microwave sensors like those on the SMAP mission, impact the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth by enabling a more comprehensive analysis of the retrieved data. This includes addressing challenges such as polarization dependence and limited degrees of information, facilitating a global-scale assessment with enhanced accuracy.

Expectation.Question: Why would increasing the number of observation channels potentially limit the retrieval performance of soil moisture data?
Expectation.Answer: Increasing the number of observation channels could lead to a situation where the model estimations do not match the observations, thus increasing the probability of discrepancies and potentially limiting the retrieval performance due to increased complexity.

Expectation.Question: Why might the polarization-dependent vegetation optical depth product be significant in the context of microwave remote sensing?
Expectation.Answer: The polarization-dependent VOD product is significant because it considers the polarization dependence of vegetation effects, which is often ignored in current retrieval algorithms, thereby providing more accurate and nuanced insights into vegetation water status and biomass dynamics.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of multi-channel collaborative algorithms in retrieving soil moisture and vegetation optical depth from satellite observations?
Judgmental.Answer: The multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) is effective as it leverages the self-constraining relationships between parameters and theoretical conversion relationships between channels to retrieve surface parameters. It does not rely on auxiliary data and suits various payload configurations. The algorithm's performance is further validated by comparing soil moisture retrieval results against networks like the International Soil Moisture Network and the Soil Climate Analysis Network, demonstrating superior accuracy compared to other SMAP products.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the challenges associated with increasing observation channels in soil moisture retrieval, and what strategies might be employed to address them?
Judgmental.Answer: Increasing the number of observation channels can enhance the robustness of soil moisture retrieval but might also limit performance due to mismatches between model estimations and observations. Strategies to address these challenges include developing algorithms that optimize the use of available data and employing self-calibrating frameworks to reduce dependence on auxiliary data. An example is the implementation of the ergodic form of the MCCA, which minimizes the degree of information needed and optimizes certain parameters to enhance retrieval accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways do you think ground-based microwave radiometry datasets contribute to the advancement of retrieval algorithms for satellite data in soil moisture and vegetation studies?
Judgmental.Answer: Ground-based microwave radiometry datasets are crucial for advancing retrieval algorithms as they provide detailed observation data that can be used to develop and validate new approaches, such as the multi-channel collaborative algorithm. By using these datasets, researchers can explore multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches, test algorithm performance in different environments, and refine techniques for better satellite data interpretation. These datasets help bridge the gap between satellite observations and ground truth, ultimately improving the accuracy and reliability of satellite-derived products.

Assertion.Answer: The multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) uses parameter self-calibration to leverage self-constraining relationships between parameters and theoretical conversion relationships between channels. This approach reduces dependency on auxiliary data by using a series of soil moisture values as input and optimizing parameters like Rou through a self-calibrating process, which enhances retrieval accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure why increasing the number of observation channels might limit the retrieval performance of soil moisture data.
Assertion.Answer: While increasing observation channels can potentially make retrieval more robust, it also raises the probability that model estimations may not match observations due to increased complexity and potential overfitting. This can create challenges in accurately retrieving soil moisture data.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how polarization differences are handled in datasets for vegetation optical depth retrieval.
Assertion.Answer: Datasets using the multi-channel collaborative algorithm generate vegetation optical depth values for both vertical and horizontal polarization. This method accounts for slight polarization differences in vegetation effects at the satellite scale, which are primarily observed in densely vegetated and arid areas.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges and limitations associated with increasing the number of observation channels in soil moisture retrieval algorithms and propose potential solutions to overcome these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges of increasing the number of observation channels include making the soil moisture retrieval more robust while potentially limiting retrieval performance due to the higher probability of model estimations not matching observations. A potential solution is to develop a multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) that utilizes information from collaborative channels to express brightness temperature analytically, which helps in ruling out the parameters to be retrieved. This approach can mitigate the limitations by ensuring that the retrieval model is robust across different frequencies and angles.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe a methodological approach for reducing the dependency on auxiliary data in the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth, and evaluate its effectiveness based on existing research findings.
Request/Directive.Answer: The ergodic form of the multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) is a methodological approach that reduces dependency on auxiliary data. It involves setting a series of soil moisture values as input and using a self-calibrating framework for parameters like surface roughness. This method aims to optimize retrieval performance under extreme conditions without relying heavily on auxiliary data. The effectiveness of this approach is demonstrated through its ability to produce the lowest unbiased root mean square deviation (ubRMSD) when compared to other methods, indicating improved accuracy in soil moisture and vegetation optical depth retrieval.
